posts.com:
>>9576402
>>9576434
I used to think the same but do the math. In SMB1 Mario takes 6.25% horizontally and 13.333% vertically (half when small). The Carrion guy takes around 5% horizontally and 12% vertically. The differences in character-to-screen ratio alone don't explain why retro games look the way they do that modern games can't quite capture.

Instead I'm sure it has more to do with how levels are designed for the widescreen format. When expanding the screen area to 16:9, there is now a lot of emptiness, so you fill it up with new details rather than keeping the amount of detail* per screen at constant. Too many things grab your attention at once and the minimalism suffers.

This might happen naturally due to modern level editor software allowing the painting of tiles like pencil tool in photoshop without having to pay attention to how the ratios come across in the actual game. Check out old level design sheets where the developers HAD to design in "pages" because of limitations. A viewfinder of sorts.

I'm sure there are examples of modern 2D indie titles that do combine tile-based pixel art and widescreen well without evoking that infamous "zoomed out" feel when playing them.

* What constitutes "detail" is a little amgibuous but I like referring to Braid, where a central principle of the art direction was that things farther from the player are drawn with broader strokes so they add less clutter to the view where it's not needed.

people like you don't get what "soul" is. when you see people enjoying it, you can't feel it. so you make up some strawman argument how everyone but you is some basement dweller manchild.
big part of old video games is their distinctive aesthetics. every game looked slightly different. sometimes, it was purely due to technical limitations—like GB's small screen, or PS1's jittery polygons and textures. even CRTs had their own distinctive look. all this resulted in unexpected, but interesting things that that expressed something.
when people like you look at things, they don't see it. maybe you've been conditioned that old = bad, and everything you don't see = just boomers' nostalgia / manchildren being manchildren. regardless, you won't find it modern games, because they have just 1 acceptable style—realism. it's devoid of any added expression, it's just a dry representation of reality, as bland and unimaginative as a news program or weather forecast.
the very nature of AAA "huge open world" games in widescreen is directly the opposite of comfy. the Western love for gigantism and "epic" things has destroyed small, comfy games. the race for the better graphics and disregard for art has destroyed any sort of genuine artistic expression in vidya.
So yeah, you wouldn't get it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a very accomplished work of set-piece adventuring.
There's a really nice blend of giving the player agency but not too much space so the main thrust of the story does not lose momentum. It never feels like there's a dull moment or it devolves into an empty grind which was more or less the norm for JRPGs of the era.
Even to this day the pace of the game feels very modern and well calibrated.
On top of that all the characters, locations and moments are very memorable.

I'd say it's a pinnacle of a "guided JRPG".

>>9577756
It's overrated for a few reasons:
1) it does some unique/interesting things that make people perceive it to be better than it actually is
2) 90's jrpgs are massively overrated... mostly because people evaluate them in the context of their time instead of realistically comparing them against all games across all time. They also get a pass for a lot of things just due to the storyline and anime feel.
3) Games that reached mainstream in pre 2005 days get elevated to some untouchable status, but if you actually play other games from the same time period or even modern indie games you'll see that it's not that unique.

With that being said, it's a good game. Not life changing.

I had the similar history with this game.

There are many things in the second game that are there "just so it is like the first game", such as the whole melody thing, except it doesn't fit in Earthbound and doesn't have an explanation. The first game also had more freedom, more exploration, and more importantly, more challenge, which is why Earthbound was still a disappointment.
However, the first game lacked in dungeons and in actual bosses (starting half way through the game, you're given a freebie against every boss, and they're not numerous to begin with). In comparison the second game shined in that regard: many and varied dungeons, many bosses.

Maybe it's because I didn't wait so long to play this game (though I still played it rather late in relation to when it was released). Although I'm not the kind of person to let others influence what I should like or not, positively or negatively, but I should mention I'm not the biggest RPG fan or non-action games in general (though I did enjoy some classic ones like Dragon Quest III).
I don't know what people like OP expect from this game, but I was pleased with Earthbound: seeing enemies on the map and even being able to sneak behind them/instakill weaker enemies was a pretty welcome change from most other RPGs, that alone made me enjoy it more than most.
The HP rolling mechanic made the turn based menu combat somewhat a bit more dynamic than in other games, too.
The limited inventory was, I think, clever on the dev's parts as it encourages actually spending items instead of hoarding like a scrub.
I actually played this game because of Keiichi Suzuki's music, as I love his band Moonriders and his other many music projects, he's a legend. And Shigesato Itoi's writing is also a nice condiment.
I was also drawn in by the simple, colorful art direction, it's very quintessential 16-bit.
Again not sure what people like OP expect, but I thought it was above average for sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What EB did good:
>enemy encounters visible on the map instead of random encounters means you can actually tell if you need to heal before you reach an exit or not
>also allows you to see new enemies in areas before you fight them
>rolling HP counters allow for recovery from fatal attacks if you can get some healing in fast enough, adding a rare sense of urgency to turn-based combat
>sister's storage system is a direct upgrade from normal item bank systems, since it can be accessed anywhere you can find a phone
>phones acting as save points and item storage access points means you have frequent access to both, including inside of dungeons
>L-button acting as a 2nd A button allows you to play mostly one-handed for easy grinding or walking around and talking to NPCs
>auto-win mechanic speeds up grinding since you don't have to fight weak enemies at all
>built-in optional hint system for new players to prevent them from getting stuck
What EB did bad:
>condiment system might as well not exist, better to have a full load of healing items instead of half a load of slightly buffed healing items
>prayer might as well not exist, since Paula's attack magic is far more reliable and less dangerous to the party
>pizza delivery serves no point, since you can buy better healing items without having to wait
>homesickness mechanic is pure tedium and only serves to slow the game down
>combat direction encounter system is rarely used as on paper, instead it's mostly grey head-on encounters, the rare red when caught while trying to run away, and the green against weaker enemies that run away and you corner
>last half of the game has a lot of backtracking, and the final area is just a level check with a healing/save point so you can grind until you can pass it
>mushroom status has annoying interface screw effect on map which just slows things down
>bicycle is completely worthless the moment you get Paula until you drop her off at home at the end of the game

>>9569786
Earthbound's translation is famous for being one of the best and most faithful ones out there considering how hard it would normally be to translate a game like this barring legal changes(Red Cross being removed, Coca Cola trucks being changed, Grateful Dead Valley being changed Peaceful Rest Valley, Naked Ness being censored, Monopoly tournmanent being changed to Strip Poker etc.) and some stupid shit the translator changed such as Paula's line about how she "would have started crying" if Ness didn't show up to save her because the translator was a soiboy feiminist(this inadvertently ruins the RPG satire about how LV1 Paula is weak and powers up throughout the game).

But overall it's a fantastic localization and recently somebody did a hack called "Mother 2 Perfect Edition" which for the most part keeps his script and just fixes the shit that needed fixing and it shows how well the original translation holds up.
Only thing I have against Perfect Edition is that they still kept the name "Giygas" and didn't change it to the proper "Gyiyg". This stupid fanboy shit really annoys me because I've seen many people who think that Gyiyg(or Giegue) from Mother 1 and Giygas are two different entities when they are clearly the same villain and Itoi literally even makes it clear in a 1992 preview for Mother 2 saying that "Gyiyg attacked them again".
People still get confused to this day due to the names being different in the translations.

>Nintendo of America's Dan Owsen began the English localization project and converted about ten percent of the script before moving to another project.[14] Marcus Lindblom filled Owsen's position around January 1995.[34] Lindblom credits Owsen with coining some of the game's "most iconic phrases", such as "say fuzzy pickles".[14] Lindblom himself was given liberties to make the script "as weird as [he] wanted", as Nintendo wanted the script to be more American than a direct translation would be.[34] He worked alone and with great latitude due to no divisional hierarchies.[17][nb 10] Lindblom was aided by Japanese writer Masayuki Miura, who translated the Japanese script and contextualized its tone,[14] which Lindblom positively described as "a glass half full".[34]

Lindblom was challenged by the task of culturally translating "an outsider's view of the U.S." for an American audience.[34] He also sought to stay true to the original text, though he never met or spoke with Itoi.[34] In addition to reworking the original puns and humor, Lindblom added private jokes and American cultural allusions to Bugs Bunny, comedian Benny Hill, and This Is Spinal Tap.[34] Apart from the dialogue, he wrote the rest of the game's text, including combat, prompts and item names.[14] As one of several Easter eggs, he named a non-player character for his daughter, Nico, who was born during development. While Lindblom took the day off for her birth,[34] he proceeded to work 14-hour days[14] without weekends for the next month.[34]

I knew the argument would be "but they made the world bigger". With what, gimmicky half-assed locations that break the setting? Oh I know, it's not "just" Egypt, it's le quirky Egypt. OK. What does it have to do with modern day America? This breaks the whole "everyday life / modernity / aliens" setting of EB.
More importantly, this is far closer to cliche locations in video games. Yeah, give us more sewers with bats, ice world, lava world, etc. Because that's why people play Earthbound, to play a generic RPG with half-assed mechanics.
>And I don't see why you're complaining so much about Scaraba, Dalaam and the Prehistoric World since none of them last that long.
Just because they're short doesn't mean they are good. And jumping locations every time breaks any sense of continuity.
I simply believe that something needs to tie things together. Winters is at least tied into plot because Jeff lives there, there's a cast of characters there that make you feel some sort of connection to the place.
In a perfect world, I'd make Summers a part of Eagleland, and you go there either by bus or by plane to keep with the "modern life" theme. Expand it and make it into a parody of 80s Miami or Cali, with pastel suits, cops, etc. I'd take 1 actually well-written location vs 5 half-assed ones.
Then instead of going on world tour, how about going somewhere else in America? Again, just as an example, a parody of famous places like Hollywood, Las Vegas, and so on. Tie old characters into it, like Blues Bros landing a movie deal, then blowing all their cash in casinos. And finally going back to your small home town to contrast it with the "big world".
That's how you get a far more cohesive atmosphere that makes sense. Mother 1 managed to reach peak cohesion, as everything was part of 1 big map. That said, it didn't focus on plot or atmosphere that much, but regardless, the cohesion is 10/10 for a NES RPG.

I played Earthbound on ZSNES about the time Mother 3 was being translated. My opinion at the time was that it had that comfy Super Nintendo vibe, a little simplistic but enjoyable to play. The atmosphere of each new location kept me going even though the combat was mostly bashing through everything. They made it feel less tedious than Earthbound Zero and progressing through the game was more rewarding too. Although the story in general is emotionally flat and they expect a big payoff out of nowhere when everything leading up to the ending is mostly nonsense.

https://youtu.be/n2iATlS4mUE

Then I played Mother 3 which is one of my favorite video games. Shorter than Earthbound but everything has more depth. Bosses require strategy. Characters feel like real people. An actual story with layers. Beautifully composed music. Detailed sprite animations. And the same moment to moment goodness that kept me playing Earthbound but even more compelling. They put a lot of personality and humanity into Mother 3, it really feels alive. If you don't like it I don't care what you like.

>>9567006
It was mostly obscure in the 1990s and then would build up a massive cult following during the 2000s, largely starting with people trying to find out who the fuck Ness was when they unlocked him in Smash, which was probably the best marketing the game ever had, but also via the wide proliferation of emulation, where many people found it online just because they were looking for games and it stood out (like in my case).
By the 2010s, it was fairly well known in 'serious' gaming circles, if you played a lot of JRPGs (or were just into older games), you would almost certainly have some sort of passing mental image of the game just by word of mouth, you most likely had seen screenshots, and plenty sought it out based on its reputation alone. Many argue that its reputation is greatly exaggerated, and that may be true, but fact is that it's an odd game with a quirky charm which stood out, and there was preciously little else like it.

Toby Fox wasn't some sort of turbo hipster seeking out the most elusive games imaginable for inspiration, he was one of a huge number of people who heard about it through word of mouth and gravitated towards it because it sounded appealing to him.
I'll state with confidence that Earthbound has not been obscure for the better part of two decades.
Obscure would be something like Meat Puppet, where it does bear a visual visual style which stands out, but beyond that wasn't really interesting or greatly compelling in any sense, nor was it really that fun to play, and so it went unnoticed by the world, forgotten about, the few who remember certainly not recommending it to other people.

I simply prefer challenge in real time gameplay, where I typically have to think on my feet and size up the situation as it develops while reacting fast enough.
Even then I find the inventory management aspect of Earthbound an entertaining one, and I was a little surprised upon making that realization, that it was testing my ability to manage limited inventory space, almost a little like a Resident Evil game, if not as constricting.

Other than that, you can use a quick button press for interacting with objects and characters, and though the battles aren't maybe a complex visual extravaganza, the colored shapes and patterns warping and shifting like they do actually stands out a lot for the time, and even still a very long time after.

Buy a crt.

A decent consumer grade is easily affordable.
>But they're impossible to find!
If you're anywhere close to a city, facebook marketplace, craigslist, offer up, literally any locals listings will have some. If you're in a remote area you might have to travel a bit, or just be patient and take a week or two checking occasionally until one pops up, but really they're easy to find.
>But they're huge and a waste of space!
They come in all sizes. Many late consumer ones were miniaturized to the point they were designed for kitchens and other secondary spaces, these ones are perfect if you're constrained by space.
Also, having a decent crt opens you up to being able to enjoy ALL retro systems, none of which are designed to be played on anything else. Just fucking bite the bullet and get one anon, trust me. I'd say keep an eye out for one that has component if you want ps2, ps2 over component looks gorgeous. But really any half decent consumer grade crt will serve you tremendously better than an hdmi adapter. Fuck, it's probably way cheaper to get a crt than an actually decent hdmi scaler for it.

Unified RAM doesn't help when texture cache is only 4kb and bottlenecks the whole system when it has to be explicitly asked to constantly fetch new data from RAM. PS1 texture cache on the other hand is an associative cache so it takes no CPU cycles to be updated and VRAM size is the only limit.

Ok, since you guys continue to insist, let's check MK Trilogy closely.
First of all, MK games have simplistic backgrounds with many tiling and repeating elements. Compare this with CPS2 games that have more big and unique, sometimes animates objects in their backgrounds.
Next, the chatacters animations. MK Trilogy sprites are very thin and don't have much unique animations. SF Alpha games are kind of simple too but Darkstalkers and Marvel vs games have more elaborate attack animations that take a large chunk of screen (and VRAM). MK Trilogy being this lightweight on animations is pretty much confirmed by the PS1 version: it easily holds 4 unique characters for 2 on 2 combat in PS1 RAM - when one character is defeated the game doesn't stop to load the second one from the disc. No Capcom game manages to have four complete and unique characters in a single fight on PS1 because they take much more memory than Mortal Kombat ones.
N64 has more RAM and doesn't have to deal with loading from the disk at all, so it allows SIX unique characters in 3 on 3 combat. Great, right? But here's the deal: the animation quality is worse than in PS1 version. So while there are six characters in N64 RAM, even having only two of them on screen, N64 can't animate them as fast as PS1 version. This is barely a cart size issue - adding a couple of frames to each character standing idle animation would make them look a whole lot smoother and this takes a very little space of ROM. MKT ROM has a enough of padding (aka unused space) for this. Even without using the unused space they could just remove that fancy MK logo in flames title screen and shitty looking MK1 stages and add better animation instead. But they didn't because N64 can't run it as smooth anyway.

There are certainly no 1800 sprites in Mario Kart. It makes a heavy use of composed sprites, aka sprites made from separate elements. Car is animated separately, wheels are animated separately and superimposed over thr car sprite. And then finally the chracter sprite is added on top. Using dynamic palettes for car colors you may "construct" unique sprites for every racer. The sprites themselves are very nicely and smoothly animated but they are very small in size. And finally, the game doesn't run at 60 fps. It runs at 30 and it's enough to fetch needed data from VRAM to buffer. A 2D fighting game at 30 fps would be a big downgrade.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9562805
>N64 could use the cart rom chip like RAM and stream data much faster than any optical media console on the market
And just to add to this, no cart based system actually does this. It still has to use RAM or different caches in between. The question is how fast can it fetch the data? Not to mention that many N64 games had to use compressed graphics so the system had to take the data from the cart, then uncompress it to RAM and only then it could use it. It wasn't free.
The system that operates very similar to what you describe is Neo Geo. I don't remember exact details but SNK didn't bother with ROM sizes and memory costs and used the biggest ones available because they could sell the carts at a big cost anyway. And then NG architecture allowed them to stream the graphics from ROM to RAM almost for free. N64 was built with different strengths in mind (fast 3D scene calculations) and it wasn't optimized to toss large sprites around with the same ease.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So CPS2 games use frame skipping to enable their turbo modes. The higher turbo mode the more frames are skipped.
But instead you could do this in reverse. You can run the gameplay logic at 60 fps internally while only displaying 50 fps sprite updates but stretching out the time the frame is on screen to make the gameplay speed still the "normal" speed*. This won't have much of an effect on the visual appearance of the game because sprites are often held on screen for multiple frames anyway so rarely will an important frame get skipped. It would result in some animations being longer than normal.**

There were other tricks used in the PS1 ports that should work here. Changing the hit sparks to 3d graphics is the first thing. The life bars could also be 3d. That's a little bit of memory savings. I think you could probably do something for the in-game timer to make it out of 3d graphics as well. Not numbers but maybe something like a two colored wheel that runs out.

*Tournament players would cry about the slowness but it is what it is.
**This would make occasional differences to the gameplay by having a move be one or two more frames of animation longer on screen resulting in something that would usually be safe on block to be punishable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563434
>It would result in some animations being longer than normal.**
Thinking over it again the animations would be the same length but what you would do is repeat the same sprite as before or after the sprite you frame skipped over.

So if you were doing a 1/6 frame skip you'd skip every sixth frame and replace it with either the frame in front of it or behind it. You could make this alternate if you wanted, or come up with more elaborate plans.
I *think* this should result in a significant saving of resources without making too much of a hit on the gameplay since the arcade version is typically played in "Turbo" mode that employs a frame-skip. So players are used to that and accept it. But here instead of using the frame skip to increase gameplay speed you're keeping the same speed but saving resources to free up time for the N64 hardware to keep up.
Again, this does result in the game running in what in the arcade version is the slow "normal" speed option.

The 64DD got hit with bad timing. It didn't really do anything other than offer more storage space and the plan was that cartridges would be fine for most games and the 64DD would be an inexpensive format for ones that needed 64MB. But maskROM prices unexpectedly dropped significantly during development which negated the need for a cheaper alternative. Once you could put 32MB and 64MB ROMs inside a cartridge for a reasonable price what was the point? Nintendo barely even released the thing. Even they knew it was pointless and only sold it by mail order to recoup what they could. Had it not been mostly done already they probably would have canceled it.

posts.name: Anonymous

Interesting thread that is probably related.
https://www.reddit.com/r/EmuDev/comments/ug5ere/about_texture_caches/

>I wrote a texture cache for an emulator many years ago when we were emulating Primal Rage on the Xbox. The total size of the textures were larger than the total amount of ram available on the Xbox so we compressed each texture using deflate and then loaded and unpacked them as they were needed. I used a simple linked list of textures and every time a texture was used it was moved to the head of the texture list. I used a map to quickly locate which textures were already unpacked in memory and which ones needed to be loaded from the CD. When a texture needed to be loaded, the last used texture (at the tail of the linked list) was discarded and the new texture was asynchronously loaded & unpacked and added to the head of the linked list.

From a real N64 developer

>We streamed audio and animation data off the cart during game play, we could have certainly gotten the audio streamed off CD and probbly some of the animation. But we'd have needed bigger internal buffers.

>Back to the original question, i was a pretty big limitation, as mentioned it wasn't a cache in the traditional sense it was an explicitly loaded block of memory that was the only place you could render from. It could not be updated mid triangle, so if you wanted a texture that wouldn'y fit, you were stuck with adding more tris and doing more explict loads, which generally led to poor performance.
What was worse was that enabling trilinear split the cache in half, so it was a 2K block of memory for the largest MipMap.

>It required thought and some understanding of the technical limitations on the art side to work around.

https://forum.beyond3d.com/threads/how-bad-a-limitation-was-the-4k-texture-cache-in-n64.40696/post-1101016

From reading this thread and some of the linked materials it is my understanding that one of the big bottlenecks is that the N64 texture cache is too small for a CPS2 16x16 and 32x32 tile size.

If each color value for each pixel is a byte then that's

16*16*3 = 768 bytes per tile.

32*32*3 = 3072 bytes per tile

4 KB = 4000 bytes

So the tiles will fit. Is it then just a question of speed moving textures in and out of cache?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9571169
>From reading this thread and some of the linked materials it is my understanding that one of the big bottlenecks is that the N64 texture cache is too small
But a 2d game doesn't have to use polygons. The N64 has programmable "microcode"... meaning there is like an interface layer for using the hardware and this can be changed by the programmer, which was done in advanced games like those by Factor 5. There were some alternate microcodes provided by SGI including one for 2d. Anyway, the texture cache issue relates to the 3d rendering pipeline. An optimised 2d game with custom microcode would probably not have any issues at all relating to texture cache. For example, the framebuffer can be written to directly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9572262
The point of texture cache is the renderer can access textures in cache as it is rendering, as in, on a per-polygon basis. So that's a process where it's iterating through geometry and applying textures as it goes and it is optimised for that. Quite a few games write to the frame buffer directly for HUD and menus. I'm sorry, I don't have an in-depth knowledge of the N64 architecture. The only way to know which games used which microcode would be to decompile them or to get that information from the developers themselves. AFAIK, no 2d N64 games have been decompiled (Paper Mario doesn't count, obviously). The N64 developer manual has been online for a while and this is the part that talks about microcode, https://ultra64.ca/files/documentation/online-manuals/functions_reference_manual_2.0i/ucode/microcode.html . The N64's graphic chip, SGI's "Reality Co-Procssor" is much more complicated than the hardware in prior consoles, where you were literally just writing background scroll values to hardware registers. SGI came from a very different world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Spider-Man vs. The Kingpin was probably the 1st video game to do the character justice, and for that it deserves a lot of credit. Apparently 2/3 of Genesis owners had this at some point, it was a system seller for SOA, following their strategy of acquiring popular IPs to rival what Nintendo had to offer, before Sonic came along at least. I think this was the 1st time where Peter Parker was somewhat incorporated into the mechanics, with the photographs that make you money so you can affort to make your web fluid, it adds depth in both the lore and gameplay, so it's really a quite welcome feature. Another thing that this did, that the previous Spider-Man adaptations didn't, was having an actual story that develops as it goes along, instead of some text in the manual or an opening cutscene to set the plot, you have cutscenes between all levels that show Spider-Man's thought process as to where he should go next to find the keys to disarm Kingpin's bomb and it's great to see, it's immersive and captures the feeling of reading a comic book more than anything that came before it. One more thing I love, that few Spider-Man video games did as well as this one, was the atmosphere, it feels dark, not too dark or edgy, nothing like that, but serious and grim, you feel the stakes through the music and graphics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9571324
Honestly not that big of a deal all things considered. Being able to actually manually aim up and down does confer you some advantages, but usually not very significant ones, because the vertical auto-aim in the original is generally pretty well behaved and helpful. The main one would be making it easier to engage enemies at a far distance, with the odd occurrence where you want to shoot something further away while some Cacos are above your desired line of fire and auto-aim would have caused a problem, but that last one isn't that common in my experience.
It does make Doom 2's final boss a lot easier, but the loss isn't substantial to me because he's not a particularly excellent fight or anything, and shootable switches are very rare in the iwads.

>>9571378
Nah, I have a gun.

>>9571416
More or less. Unless you're speedrunning, which most people don't, I don't really see a reason to be strict about it, and even then you could actually develop your own category which allows it if you just really wanted to.
I think it's well worth experiencing how the gameplay was like originally, just to get a feel for it and then also better appreciating how things developed, but I'm not gonna hold my gun to your head if you decide you're just sick of it, I play with GzDoom about as often as I play with Woof.
I feel the same way for the "Infinite Monster Height" thing, there's good reason that's something which nobody went back on, and sometimes it actually can give flying monsters some pretty serious tactical advantages the map author never foresaw, possibly making things a lot harder, so that evens out with the advantages you get yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9571437
I would actually suggest to turn off the vertical auto aim when using full freelook, that gives you far greater and faster control of moving from target to target, especially in tight spots.

>>9571448
I tend to use jumping when playing in GzDoom just because I like using it for maneuvering in combat, an example is if you got cornered by some monsters, you could jump up and run over their heads to escape them, and as long as you move fast enough they can't eat your feet. Likewise for crouching, such as ducking down by a chest-high barrier or object to avoid incoming fire, and sometimes in very tight combat where I may duck down to avoid an incoming projectile just in time, because I don't have the room to move any direction but down.

I think that sort of thing is fun, and adds onto the already fun and dynamic combat Doom has. I'm however very conscious of how that can break some levels, in some ways quite a lot, so I generally make sure to not use jumping or crouching as to reach areas which it's clear I'm not supposed to reach yet, barring maybe using a shortcut to get back to somewhere I already have access to.

>>9574513
>Any that had it as the default?

Sin and Punishment was conceived to utilize it.
From Iwata Asks, Sin and Punishment: Star Successor:

>Maegawa: All right. It all began with the Nintendo 64 controller. At the time Nintendo had suggested two ways of holding it, left position and right position, but most games called for the right position.
>Iwata: Super Mario 64 used the right position, so everyone used that.
>Maegawa: We started talking about how no one hardly ever used the left position, even though you can perform independent actions with it.
>Iwata: You can do some unique controls, but no one used it.
>Maegawa: Right, no one used it. But we thought it would make for interesting game operation and started development.
>Iwata: So Sin & Punishment began with you deciding to make full use of the left position.
>Maegawa: Yes. We thought maybe you could aim with the analog stick and move with the D-pad in the left position.
>Iwata: How did that work out as you began development?
>Maegawa: We realized that the independent operations in the left position would be unexpectedly hard for players the first time they tried it.
>Iwata: Because they'd never done it before.

https://iwataasks.nintendo.com/interviews/wii/sinandpunishment/0/0/

What was your first experience playing Doom?
>late 1994 sunday afternoon
>7yr old me, obsessed with Mortal Kombat 2
>don't read gaming magazines, out of the loop about PC games in general
>dad brings home a big box with cool artwork and floppies inside
>"drop your nintendo, anon, I've got something here"
>"nooo dad, not your simulators again"
>(I actually loved playing F117 with him but all I wanted to play at the moment was Mortal Kombat 2)
>"It's a shooter game like contra but it's in first person like you are watching the action with your own eyes, anon"
>"yeah dad, like in your simulators. This is a really stupid idea"
>dad switches on the PC. I don't like it much because "Super Nintendo has cooler games" and I'm always afraid to break it somehow. I am not allowed to switch it on and use it on my own
>Windows 3.1 starts but dad shuts it down to "free the memory"
>starts a blue-windowed shell instead
>I am looking at the game box while the game installs. It says Doom II
>some of my classmates were joking about Doom when the lights went flickering in the class. Never seen the game myself and never knew that there are two of them
>after the setup process the game is launched, first level starts, I see pic related
>"huh, these stairs look cool"
>dad moves around, shoots
>"definitely cool"
>I ask to try myself and for the rest of the session it's just me playing and dad watching me play and giving advice
>we finish the game a couple of weeks later. Keyboard only, frequently getting scared and lost in the levels, save scumming
>It's the best gaming experience in my life, thanks dad.

Fucking horrible game even for 1993 standards. Cannon Fodder and Syndicate left it in the dust that very same year. Hired Guns, while it isn't 3D, offers much, much more variety and customisation and an incredible 4 player co-op gameplay never seen before in an FPS game. Doom was an absolute snoozefest that became boring within a week once the novelty wore off. It had a really huge mass appeal because anyone with more than half a braincell could get into it. The midi music was fucking awful, repetitive, and aggravating. Its a tech demo, not a video game. It's not the CoD of it's era, at least CoD games are actual games with actual challenge and replayability.

>>9560493
For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993 and have about half left over (people didn't do this at the time). Doom only needed a 486 to run well, which hovered at around $1000 at the time, and would keep dropping. By the time Doom 2 was in stores, a 486 computer with a mouse and the memory to use it together with the game would be WELL under the $1000 mark. Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two, with the original game's first episode being widely available dirt cheap, or even for free. Most people probably experienced it this way, many using the 386 or even 486 at their school, university, or workplace.
That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.

To conclude, your dad should have pulled out, because clearly he couldn't afford to raise you if the prospect of playing Doom was prohibitively expensive. You must have grown up somewhere incredibly poor and undeveloped.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561281
>For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993
You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
>Doom only needed a 486 to run well
With basic ass 486DX-33, you needed to set the quality to minimum and reduce the window size by 25% or less to get a comfortable framerate.
>which hovered at around $1000 at the time
More like $2000 for the basic ass 486DX-33. Even a shitty 386DX would be well over $1000. A bare minimum spec PC with 486DX2 66MHz, the minimum CPU for running Doom comfortably, would run you up for almost $2500. 486SX was choppy as hell and with 486DX you needed to scale down the screen size by something like 25% and set the quality down to minimum, but it will still get choppy when the game throws more enemies at you. Not sure if using more RAM than the minimum spec of 4MB will help the game run better, I suppose it does at higher quality and resolution.
>Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two
More like in half or less.
>That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.
Just not Doom, it was one of the most demanding games back then. You'd have much better luck playing it on atari jaguar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561337
>You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
If you wanted the full 35fps at all times, sure, but the vast majority of people hadn't ever experienced that with a game of that graphical fidelity (compare to Ultima Underworld). The game being able to stay consistently above 20fps was already incredibly fluid for most people at the time. Compare.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=foHUXGzHOx0

Never mind that you definitely did not have to spend up to $2500. You didn't have to buy a complete pre-built, you could build your own, even reuse components from an older computer (such as the screen, keyboard, mouse, speakers), depending on what you start out with, you could even replace the 386 on the motherboard with a 486, and a weaker 486SX can be replaced with a better 486DX, the previous one can be sold off to cover expenses. You can also save a lot by skipping a CD-ROM drive, which would start at like $200 alone by 1994, Doom was available on floppies.

If you had already invested in a 386 prior, you didn't need to spend a fortune on getting decent performance with Doom, nor did you if you had a lower end 486. Some computers with 486s could also be upgraded to Pentium, which could become relevant for later games.

That's 1993, things would change quite quickly over 1994.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558129
October 1994, I was on a week long vacation from school, visiting my now dead cousin, who owned a 100 Mhz Intel 486 PC with a load of games on the HD. He was a university student at the time and had the connections to get all sorts of shit. Thanks to him I was able to play all the major releases at the time, because my own family were poorfags. Anyway...

So there was Doom, sitting on his hard drive. I was already familiar with Wolfenstein 3-D and Doom was said to be from the same guys, so, together with all the media hubbub surrounding it, I already sort of knew what to expect. I booted DOOM.EXE on my cousins MS-DOS 6.22 system and over the next few hours, my mind was fucking blown.

This thing had everything that Wolf 3-D lacked: Stairs and height differences, different levels of lighting, and actual 3 dimensional pillars. The guns had just the right amounts of balls, and the satanic imagery just the right amount of your classic 1990's edge. Video game violence was the hot topic in news at the time, so being able to play this naughty, forbidden thing at just the right age as a 14 year old teenager made you feel like a proper rebel.

I ended up staying at my cousins place the whole weekend, where I finished the full game. I came prepared: I had the cheat codes, which I copied from a video games magazine earlier at my local library, so my 1st time beating Doom was actually with cheats enabled. Even then, it was a tight experience. Even with IDDQD on, my 1st encounter with the Cyber Demon almost had me shit myself. Doom was fucking radical.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9575386
I was damaged so fucking badly by that.

A lot of people who try out games like Doom when they're really young may be provided with the cheat codes so they won't just eat shit all the time. To me, cheats quickly became a crutch and I would play any and all game with any cheats I could find, and would often shy away from games where I couldn't cheat. I was fucking bad at videogames, and I was a sore goddamn loser who couldn't cope with any setback. I wasn't a scrublord, no, for I was actually the scrubkaiser.

One day when I'm like 14 or 15, checking out Duke Nukem 3D, a game I had fooled around in with cheats before, my brother actually talks me into giving it a go without cheats. Fuck me, the experience was conclusively better, I don't think I had ever had that much fun with videogames before, and I felt like a king beating the final boss and watching Duke score a goal with his eyeball, proudly proclaiming...
>GAME OVER!

Games turned exciting in ways they weren't to me before, because I finally allowed myself to be challenged. It was lifechanging, I set out on giving them all proper goes, Doom, Goldeneye, Half-Life, Quake, Return To Castle Wolfenstein, Rise Of The Triad, and they were all amazing in ways they never were to me before.

On Final Doom, my enjoyment with that had largely been to play with no monsters and just look at things and listen to the cool music which was different from Doom 2 (I played the first one a little later), because the levels were scarier and I was a chickenshit initially. After my rehabilitation, I finally got to experience them for what they were really worth, and I would see them in a very different light.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was walking through Sears with my Mom and had to check out the PC area. One of the computers on display had DOOM running on it. I had never seen it before but immediately recognized it as a Wolfenstein 3D-style game and played it there for a couple minutes.

A few weeks (probably) later, Dad came home from work and came into the den with some floppies he wanted to install. I was on the couch adjacent to the computer. He got the installer going and I happened to look over his shoulder at the screen, which had a bland-looking progress bar with a little text. "DOOM?" I asked him. "Good eye," he replied. A nice memory.

posts.com: As a kid who grew up being a Sega and Sonic fan, I enjoyed it and Sonic Adventure 2, even liked Sonic Shuffle. Still somewhat felt like old school Sonic (at least Adventure 1 did), and raising Chao with friends was a lot of fun, but even back then I could tell that the series was heading in the wrong direction and that it'd lost much of its original charm and identity, and I don't think the franchise has ever recovered from it. Sonic Heroes was the final nail in the coffin for me, was just lame, cheesy, and mediocre all around. I'm glad to see people who grew up with this Sonic still enjoy it and support the series, but I don't understand why so many of them hate on old school Sonic so much, except as a reaction to old school fans hating on Modern Sonic. I can understand the Genesis games might not be the most engaging to play today, but how can they not see its good qualities?

posts.com:
>>9573467
It's a great game that gets overhated because it's not Mario 64. Yeah, the game can be a little janky at times, but it's a 3D game from the 90s, every 3D game from that period was janky in one way or another, but many of them are fondly remembered, yet for some reason, this game is the exception. It's a shame too, because I kinda stayed away from this game for awhile because almost everyone here treats this game like it's the spawn of Satan for reason. I finally caved and tried it out for myself time and I honestly don't understand where all the hate comes from. The story is pretty decent, the music is great, I loved the hub world designs, and almost all the stages are really fun. The only negative things I can say about this game, really, is
>that the other playable characters who aren't Sonic, Tails and Knuckles feel like they over-stay their welcome a bit.
>I could do without Big's portion of the game
>I love that the game doesn't really hold your hand that much and you just have to figure out what to do and where to go next on your own, but I think there were some times where I felt like a clue would be in order. Like in Amy's part of the story, for the finale, you have to go to the crash site of the Egg Carrier. The thing is, I had no idea where the site was and the only hint the game tells you is "Go to crash site". I wandered around Station Square, Mystic Ruins and Final Egg forever until I noticed the boat at the end of the docks in Station Square and felt like an idiot.

Overall, though, I think Sonic Adventure is a really solid game, especially for the being the first 3D Sonic game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561476
>And less than 50 were built.

1993 was pre-internet so information is not available on the exact amount. However my research confirms around 25 to 30 Ridge Racer Full Scale Units were exported for Western/Foreign markets. They were spread across the USA, UK, Spain, France, Middle East, Australia, etc.

And around 20 Ridge Racer Full Scale were used in Asian markets. Namco themselves kept several units in reserve to use in their Namco branded theme parks and Namco arcades in Japan. Several independent arcade owners in Asia had a Ridge Racer Full Scale too. A few malls had them as well. In the 1990s, any business owner could buy it from Namco if they had the money.

Trust me. Namco would NOT invest money in a factory, put Ads in sales magazines (for arcade owners), make sales flyers, and only make a small handful of Ridge Racer Full Scale Units. You need bulk sales to make it worth the investment.

>>9563351
>are you sure? i saw one of these at pontins in prestatyn in late 90s/early 00s. If they only made 50 it's hard to imagine one would have ended up some run down holiday camp jn North Wales
No one knows the exact number for sure. Literally anyone with $250,000 to blow could have ordered a Ridge Racer Full Scale from Namco between 1993 and 1998. I'm not saying only 50 units were made. All I know is that I could only confirm around 50 with my research but more could have been made. It would not surprise me if more were manufactured.

Arcade collectors on forums like to say that only around 20 ridge racer full scale units were ever made, and pretend it was some sort of super rare machine. Which is complete bullshit. Namco would not invest millions into tooling an entire arcade factory and only make 20 units. They aren't Sega. Namco is actually well known for being financially responsible. It would not surprise me if 100 or 200 were made. I've talked to people that claim they saw Ridge Racer Full Scale in malls, movie theater lobbies, big arcades, theme parks, beach resorts, airports, etc.

>imagine one would have ended up some run down holiday camp jn North Wales
Your holiday camp probably bought them used at a big discount. During the early 2000s, many arcades were closing down because the arcade market crashed and never recovered. Businesses were selling their arcade machines on eBay and several websites for super cheap. That includes Ridge Racer Full Scale. I remember seeing them for sale. You could have gotten it for cheap if you had a few thousand dollars back then. I'm guessing a few places picked up a Full Scale for cheap and got a couple more years of use out of it until the machine broke down and was scrapped. Sucks that no one saved even one working unit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564774
Arcade business owners paid huge sums of money for arcade cabinets with the promise that they will earn their investment back in 6 months and start earning profit. Ridge Racer Full Scale was no different.

An arcade owner could pay $200,000 for Ridge Racer Full Scale. Yes that's huge for an arcade. But they could charge $5 dollars per play. Let's assume when it first came out that 500 people per day played Ridge Racer Full Scale. That $2,500 dollars a day. That's about $75,000 a month. That's $450,000 in 6 months. That's $900,000 in 1 year. It's already more than paid for itself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564825
Ah...these ski machines. These things used to be everywhere. There aren't many "old school" Namco or Sega ski arcade machines like Super Alpine racer around anymore in arcades.

These machines saw a lot of abuse. People were very rough on the machines and the foot mechanisms were prone to breaking without periodic maintenance. People slamming their whole body weight left and right would eventually cause something to break. Many of these machines would break down as years passed.

The rear projection screens also were an issue as time passed. The bulbs inside needed to be replaced after a certain amount of hours of use. The bulbs cost money, and arcade owners don't want to invest money in keeping the screen running. Especially when LCD technology is now available.

They are also very bulky. If you do see a ski machine in arcades, it's probably a new one made Raw Thrills.

I'm not saying these old school Namco or a Sega Ski Machines are rare to find...Or that they worth a lot of money. They are out there and You could definitely find one for sale if you want on some websites. But shipping is expensive and it will probably need some sort of maintenance done.

Many arcade owners simply got rid of them after several years rather than continue maintaining them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9574740
>Sega would have been extremely gun-shy about releasing any kind of power add-on for the Dreamcast.
They're retarded enough to try this sort of shit again.
But depending on pricing it could work.
They did plan for this anyway, the DC has rails on the bottom made for this. That pic is an extension for a working zip support prototype, that's a normal DC on top of it.
It wouldn't be far fetched to believe they had other plans including increasing the console's power if the thing was successful and needed it
Because how else would the DC run VF4? VF was a huge deal for Sega back then and they would port it on console no matter what the cost.
If not for more power, they would need to downgrade it by a lot if they were to port it on the base Dreamcast, even more than the PS2 version. The naomi 2 basically double the naomi/DC CPU/GPU + a transform and lightning graphic chip. I think a DC expansion pack could do with just adding another GPU and the T/L chip and some more ram.
The console was already cheap to produce in the first place so by the time Sega would feel the need to add more power to the console in say 2002-2003, those chips would be already 5 year old.
It's just a fun theory I think about sometimes, but I think it could have worked. IIRC there were rumors about this back then.

The game has some cool sub weapons/abilities in the form of animals but you can only equip two while the cheetah and the sword swing speed up one are basically mandatory if you want your controls to be somewhat palatable so you hardly ever get to use the others. I feel like you have to be ignoring all of great mechanics and design of lttp to claim this is better. For me personally Story of Thor/Beyond Oasis is a better Zelda competitor while also being a much more unique game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9575624

Resident evil 3 because:

- The most important part is, resident evil 3 is the one with most variety of female zombies. Resident evil 1does not have any female zombies. Resident evil 2 only have one type and is very rare to find(there are only like 5 of them in the entire "normal" mode). Meanwhile in resident evil 3 there are a big variety of female zombies with a lot of clothes and hair styles. Sad the fact there are no female zombies prostitutes or female zombies pole dancers, but still is good to see there are a lot of female zombies.

- By far, more weapons variety than resident evil 1.

- You can skip the boring talks by press the start button(in resident evil 1 and 2 you have to hear those boring talks everytime you play them).

- Fat male zombies(there are not a single fat zombie in resident evil 1 and 2). Thats means again, more zombies variety the better.

- In the "mercenaries" mode you can play as a traitor who looks and sounds like he is already in his early 40s(yet he is the "experts" option only).

- There are many oil barrels and dynamite around, so you can lure the enemies to them, shot at them, and when the enemies explode you can tell them "happy new year!".

- You can explore more the city than in resident evil 2.

- You can hear a music box in a puzzle.

-You can see some rain in some rooms(in resident evil 1 and 2 there are not rain at all).

The only bad thing about resident evil 3 is that it feels too short(wich is obvious because Capcom
rushed in finishing it).

But still, a better game than resident evil 1 and 2.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9575624
They are all logical continuations of each other, they are different enough that it's unfair to grade them under the same standards.

>1
Tough but fair adventure game. Best balance of horror and action, enemies are few but they are lethal

>2
Movie-like experience. Technological advances made it possible to now have many enemies at once, which was visually impressive but it changed the formula too much, and it also ramped up the action. Atmosphere and tone are objectively great so it s still a great game even if its a lot easier this time around

>3
Action game. Originally imagined as an arcadeesque spin-off action game, it was very late in the development that they decided to bring Jill back and shoehorn in a few additional areas to make it long enough for a numbered title. Hence a lot more action, faster gameplay, faster running speed and everything else that comes with it. Mechanically its the pinnacle of tank controls, it feels very smooth to play and control. It still has plenty of atmosphere but the pacing is too fast compared to the more serene feeling 1 and 2.

They are all worth playing and are very well polished games. No need to choose just one.

Nah, it was fine, unless you're opposed on-principle to the idea of Fox going around on-foot. Never understood the bitching about the controls, they were basically identical to GC Metroid Prime; if people could learn to play that, they could learn to play this. The Landmaster feels significantly more responsive than, say, the Scorpion from Halo. The Arwing is indeed slower and floatier than in 64, but that's kind of a necessity in the free roam levels where you're expected to navigate actual level geometry, as opposed to 64's all-range levels consisting of flying over empty plains.

The worst that can be said about Assault is that it's too short, completely linear, and the ground missions all have the same objective. Still easily better than Adventures and anything that came afterward.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9575076
Oblivion was pretty mediocre about dungeons. Aylied ruins and oblivion gates aren't bad in themselves, in fact I think they're pretty good when you start out (these are the parts I really like about the game), but they get pretty familiar soon enough, and they even reuse oblivion gates eventually.
This leaves forts, mines, and caves, and these are rarely worthwhile, there's seldom anything interesting to fight there, and rarely even half decent loot, usually caves are a complete waste of time with basically no loot and only weak trash mob enemies, and looting a mine you make so incredibly little money from what little ores and gems you can find (themselves barely worth anything), that they aren't worth considering.

There's a lot I dislike about Skyrim, but it makes a better effort for dungeons, you can count on finding at least something mildly useful or interesting in a random cave, even if it's maybe 100-200 gold at most in value and a potion or something, and you might stumble into something like a troll or a group of vampires even at low levels. Skyrim also makes ores and mining have an actual point, not just through the crafting system (where you've got continuous use for more ore), but with nicer ores actually being worth at least some money.
There are 8 veins of gold ore in all of Oblivion, they don't respawn, and they only give you a single gold nugget. What is that gold nugget worth? Fucking 25 gold coins, meaning that if you're thorough in searching for gold ore to plunder, you can come away with the fabulous earnings of 200 gold! WOW! THAT'S GOOD FOR REPAIRING MAYBE A LITTLE BIT OF (not-enchanted) EQUIPMENT! You can make like 1300 for scavenging all the raw silver, which is comparatively better, but it's still very poor value for your time, unfortunately consistent with how silverware is equally undervalued, so there's no point in robbing people's homes either.
They may as well not have had mines in the game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The reason it's shown as a gameboy game is because while the original gameboy just has four shades of grey, later on there was a super gameboy cartridge which let you play your gameboy games on the your SNES. For those games, there is some extra data in there for it, so it could convert these four shades to colours. This is just like extra palette data and the palettes are predetermined from the SNES master palette, so you're just saying use palette 3 (which had four colours), rather than entirely custom palettes.

The game also included coloured sprites to fill up the rest of the screen (again using the palettes) like background decoration. These are still just regular game boy games because at the time there was no gameboy colour. When the gameboy colour did come out, it had a neat little trick where on startup, you could set the game to use one particular palette as the main palette for everything. And the gameboy colour also knew how to interpret the coloured palettes (if you left it on the default main one), so even in the original pokemon games, they switched to shades of blue or green for different areas, and switch to a palette with green for the health bars and so on.

I think the reason why Yellow's palette is different is because they weren't limited to the predefined ones in the super gameboy, so they could pick from a wider range of colours for the four different ones, and they went for more vibrant ones. One thing I never tried, but would be curious to, is if you played yellow on a super gameboy, would it 'fall back' to the same palettes as red and blue?

Yeah, uncovered EPROMs aren't nearly as susceptible to data loss as is made out, especially since most are stored inside. That said it's certainly best to cover them to be safe.

The hilarious part is when you go to an estate sale and it's painfully clear the deceased was a hoarder themselves. Box after box of random junk, plastic bins full of stuff that obviously hasn't been touched in ages, all these things you know they kept telling themselves "This is an investment, one day I'll sell for big bucks!" In the end, they just have a pile of crap collecting dust just like the person next door, and it ends up getting sold for far less than they thought it was worth after they die.
I see one nearby where one dead guy had a collection of rare comics he obviously spent a great deal of time hunting down. I'm talking 1940's and 1950's era comics. Many of them were in display cases. They didn't go to some museum, or pass down to any children, they were just sold piece by piece after he died. But he obviously spent a ton of money and time getting these comics and sealing them inside of a plastic box. All that time and money on comics he couldn't even read anymore since they were sealed.
Estate sales are effectively looking at a hoarder's legacy. I think a lot less collectors would be interested in collecting if they visited estate sales and saw for themselves the end result of a lifetime of hoarding.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9576394
>>9576779
I'm glad I could reach you both.
I use a general rule for just about everything I own. "Have I touched this in the past year? If not, why do I have it?" I don't need to be surrounded by things to be happy, just the things I actually use and entertain me. I'm not gonna throw away old photos just because I haven't looked at them lately, and I'm not gonna throw away my space heater just because it didn't get cold enough to use it last year, but that's the general rule I follow to keep myself from ending up with a lot of clutter. If it's not a part of my life, it needs to get out of my life.
If it doesn't matter to you(and if it's been sitting there over a year, it probably doesn't), then why are you hanging on to it? I always hear people say "One day I'm gonna use/do X with that!" or "When I retire I'm gonna..." One day never gets here, and by the time most people retire they are resting in between visits to the doctor and dealing with maintaining their home while old and tired. It's a mental trap we fall into because it feels like making a plan for the future, when in reality we are putting something off. Why do I have this cartridge of game X that I haven't played in 2 years? Because I plan on playing it one day? Why not play it now? It's not like taking a break from your current game to play it will make the game you were playing vanish. Because I'm waiting until I finally FEEL like playing it? How much longer do I need to hang onto this item before I can get some enjoyment out of it? The lies we tell ourselves really fall apart hard when you question them.
Congrats on breaking out of the trap. Most people never will. If you don't believe me, look at how many ads encourage you to "collect the whole set!"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9570624

> weapons

I didn't express myself clearly. The ammo in SS2 and weapons in SS2 are pretty bog-standard. Pistol, Shotgun, Assault Rifle, Grenade Launcher. The only interesting weapons are the deathbeam thing which is completely useless compared to a Grenade Launcher and the stasis field generator, which is just a glorified massive stun gun that SS1 has immediately in the game.

SS1 has cooler weapon concepts that ramp up much more. You start off with the dart gun that has both tranq and dart ammo, pistols, the flechette with fucking hornet and splinter ammo which is cool, the magnum with hollow point and teflon rounds which is awesome, and at the end you get rail guns and rocket launchers, skorpion machine guns and whatnot.

The plot in SS1 is Hal9000. AI goes insane and tries to kill humanity. It's well written, all bourgeoning empire of steel careening into the sky and all that, but it's pretty simple all through the game. You foil all her individual plans to fuck up earth. Good stuff.

SS2 is philosophical debate between individualism, collectivism and the machine. You are the individual. The Many are collectivism and swarm intelligence, a bit like the Borg in Star Trek. You fuck up collectivism with the help of the Machine, but then it tries to take over again and you, the human individual have to foil the machine to retain humanity. Also it's a debate between organic life and artificial life, and you as an augmented guy are the mixture of both. There's more going on here for SS2 than SS1 imo.

>>9570947
What's mechanically better about it? All the ammo types are still variations of armor piercing and anti-personnel just with different names. The cyber hardware is cool but I mostly just use the jumpjets, shield, and skates and SS2 makes up for those with psionics, speed hypos, and armors. I like SS1 because it's pretty much a sci-fi dungeon crawl but SS2 has the benefits of the Dark engine with great AI, stim and response so you can think outside the box and do things like set yourself on fire with internalized pyrokinesis to avoid protocol droid damage, bash metal pipes to bait shotgun hybrids around corners and ambush them, Eric Brosius' fantastic sound design, and enemies that don't get stuck on corners because of 1994 pathfinding. The only things I can think of that SS1 put more effort into compared to 2 are the minigames which I don't particularly care about, and cyberspace, which I find to be a burden compared to SS2's hacking mechanics, especially when playing on the higher difficulties and you have to do the cyberspace segments in the span of 40 seconds or it resets and you take damage.

I beat it for the first time last year (Saturn/Satiator), and it was a really good experience. It reminded me a lot of Final Fantasy X to be honest in the way that it had a short running time and every battle/boss had some sort of gimmick in a good way. There were only a few nitpicks I had, but they were related to unlocking the extra dragon form.
It’s about a 20-30 hour game, and I do recommend it. It’s an RPG, but there’s enough variety in gameplay that I could see it appealing to people who aren’t necessarily fans of RPGs.
It’s not worth the insane asking price though, just pirate it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I usually don’t like RPGs all that much but this one is pretty fun. I’m more into arcade ports and action games but I liked the first two Panzer Dragoons so I decided to give this one a try. The battles are actually interesting and exploration has just enough to it to keep me playing. The story was even ok. It’s not really hard and its pretty short, but whats there is a fun time. Not too grindy. Theres just the right amount of strategy and action in the battles so that it doesn’t feel like a boring d&d simulator, and its short enough that it keeps throwing new things at you until the end.

I usually quickly get bored of even the famous highly recommended RPGs pretty quickly but for what its worth, this one kept me hooked.

To an actual RPG enthusiast though, its probably baby’s first jarpig with a funky mechanic or two thrown in.

Spamming the mountain tool is a good start. Focus on a couple of areas and build dramatic ravines, descents and cracks. A few more pronounced areas is better than a huge field of random hills. Then try to break up the straight edges inherent to the game with scenery.

>>9563554
i think it's fine, i mean the way scenario progression for the rct2 scenarios works is already quite different to how vanilla rct2 did it and infact is the cause of the weird difficulty curve of rct2
in vanilla rct2 you could just pick any scenario and there was no unlocking at all, and the expansion scenarios + any custom scenarios you had were all lumped together into a massive mess
and openrct2 already changed this years ago by implementing a more rct1 style approach where they're sorted by source games with an unlocking system. so what you're probably thinking is "vanilla" really is just how openrct2 handled it before.
plus if you really want a more rct2 accurate "progression" system then you can just disable scenario unlocking or just switch to difficulty based scenario sorting which is more like vanilla rct2 but without all of the messy organization

>>9570932
GC lost because it appealed to no one but Nintendo fans. N64 already had problems with this, but GC lost Goldeneye and a few of the 3rd parties N64 had. The crown of the multiplayer shooter console went to Xbox. For everything else, PS2 was outdoing it in every single way.
It also wasn't 1996 anymore, when Sony was literally who, and Sega was obviously fucking up in every imaginable way. It was 2001, when PlayStation was already a household name, and Xbox suddenly came as a 2nd strong rival in America, N64's biggest market.
GC also wasn't nearly as groundbreaking as N64, and basically in many ways was more of the same, while the competitors were improving. Every 6th gen console launched with analog controller. GTA3 and Halo left Nintendo lagging behind. They were no longer "ahead of their time".
Given this, GC sold as much as you'd expect. 20-something million units, which is about 60% of what N64 sold. Should have though before selling Rare and alienating all 3rd parties with their policies.

>>9572341
>Noooo no one played on PS2! Everyone only ever played on Nintendo consoles! Only Nintendo was ever good! Nintendo invented every genre and the genres that it didn't invent don't matter because they're bad!
Imaging coping so hard because your console got outsold more than 7 times by PS2.
To dispel this myth once and for all:
GC sold ~22 million units total. PS2 did ~158.
PS2 had 162 games that sold over 1 million units, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_best-selling_PlayStation_2_video_games
GC had just 35, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_best-selling_GameCube_video_games
Combined, just those PS2 games sold 403 mln units, and GC ones did just 76, which is over 5 times more. And that's not counting the vast amount of other games that sold less than a million units, there's simply more of them on PS2.
Add to this the fact that PS2 also had a slim version, and in some regions was affected by piracy, so this would drive up the number of consoles sold relative to games.
So no, people bought just as many games on PS2 if not more. The whole meme about it being used for DVD came from an old article written in the very early days when PS2 had few games.
Nintendo lost hard. Everyone played on PS2. Cope.
